laws.summary: Maryland prohibits employers from asking applicants about wage or salary history and from relying on such information in determining compensation.
requirements: Employers may not seek or rely on an applicant's wage history
Applies to oral, written, or third-party inquiries
Applicants may voluntarily disclose salary history
Employers may confirm salary history only after a job offer with compensation has been made
Retaliation for refusing to disclose salary history is prohibited
laws.notes: This is a strict statewide salary history ban.

laws.summary: Maryland requires employers to disclose wage ranges in job postings and provide pay range information to applicants and employees under certain circumstances.
laws.statute_citation: Md. Code, Labor & Employment § 3-304.1 (as amended by 2022 pay transparency law)
requirements: Job postings must include the wage range for the position
Postings must include a general description of benefits and compensation offered
Employers must provide wage range to applicants upon request
Employers must provide wage range to employees for their position upon request
Retaliation for wage discussion or requests is prohibited
laws.notes: Maryland requires pay ranges directly in job advertisements.

laws.summary: Maryland restricts non-compete agreements for low-wage employees and applies reasonableness standards for others.
requirements: Non-competes are prohibited for employees earning less than 150% of the state minimum wage
Non-competes must be reasonable in duration and geographic scope for higher earners
Must protect legitimate business interests
Overly broad restrictions may be unenforceable
laws.notes: Maryland has a statutory income threshold for enforceable non-competes.

laws.summary: Maryland restricts criminal history inquiries and requires compliance with federal FCRA procedures when using background check vendors.
laws.statute_citation: Md. Code, State Gov’t § 20-602 (Ban-the-box for certain employers); Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Certain employers cannot inquire into criminal history before an interview
If using a third-party background check, written consent is required
Must provide pre-adverse action notice with report and rights
Must provide final adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history use must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Maryland has statewide ban-the-box rules applicable to covered employers.

laws.summary: Maryland mandates paid sick and safe leave for covered employers and protects certain civic leave rights.
laws.statute_citation: Maryland Healthy Working Families Act (Md. Code, Labor & Employment § 3-1301 et seq.)
requirements: Employers with 15+ employees must provide paid sick and safe leave
Accrual generally at 1 hour per 30 hours worked
Up to 40 hours of leave per year required
Covers illness, preventive care, family care, and domestic violence situations
Employees must be allowed leave for jury duty without retaliation
laws.notes: Offer letters should not contradict statutory sick and safe leave entitlements.

laws.summary: Maryland permits workplace drug testing. Recreational cannabis use has limited employment protections depending on circumstances.
laws.statute_citation: Maryland Labor and Employment guidance; Maryland cannabis legislation
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may prohibit impairment during work
Drug testing policies should be applied consistently
Some local or industry-specific rules may impose additional limits
laws.notes: Maryland employers should carefully draft drug testing policies, especially for safety-sensitive roles.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Maryland if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Maryland Uniform Arbitration Act
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clearly written
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate overly one-sided clauses

laws.summary: Maryland follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract states otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Handbooks or policies may create implied obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Maryland law prohibits discrimination in employment on a broad range of protected characteristics, often broader than federal law.
laws.statute_citation: Maryland Fair Employment Practices Act (Md. Code, State Gov’t § 20-601 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age, disability, national origin, marital status
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters and terms must not imply exclusion or bias.

data_quality.sources: Maryland General Assembly statutes, Maryland Department of Labor, Maryland Commission on Civil Rights, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Maryland is relatively employee-protective, with mandatory pay transparency, salary history bans, paid sick leave, and income-based non-compete restrictions.
recent_developments: Pay transparency rules require salary ranges in job postings
Continued enforcement of salary history ban
Ongoing enforcement of paid sick and safe leave obligations
Income thresholds continue to limit non-compete enforceability
